metadata.title: Responsive Polymers as Smart Nanomaterials Enable Diverse Applications

Responsive polymers undergo reversible or irreversible physical or chemical modifications in response to a change in environment or stimulus, e.g., temperature, pH, light, and magnetic or electric fields. Polymeric nanoparticles (NPs), which constitute a diverse set of morphologies, including micelles, vesicles, and core-shell geometries, have been successfully prepared from responsive polymers and have shown great promise in applications ranging from drug delivery to catalysis. In this review, we summarize pH, thermo-, photo-, and enzymatic responsiveness for a selection of polymers. We then discuss the formation of NPs made from responsive polymers. Finally, we highlight how NPs and other nanomaterials are enabling a wide range of smart applications with improved efficiency, as well as improved sustainability and recyclability of polymeric systems.

sections.heading: INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
Since the beginning of the twenty-first century, increasing efforts have been devoted to the development and characterization of various stimuli-responsive polymeric systems (1, 2). By definition, stimuli-responsive polymers are those that undergo a physical or chemical change in response to an external stimulus. The selection of stimuli is vast and can include enzymatic activity, pH changes, redox reactions, magnetic fields, temperature changes, and light (3–8). In response to a stimulus, polymers may undergo either a reversible or irreversible modification in bond structure and/or molecular interactions, e.g., hydrophobic/hydrophilic interactions. These chemical modifications can lead to changes in structure or self-assembly at large length scales. Because of these attributes, responsive polymers have been termed smart or intelligent materials.
Temperature and light are two of the most common physical stimuli that have been used to induce chemical modifications within polymeric materials. In general, physical stimuli possess several intrinsic advantages: (a) noncontact and remote application, (b) tunable strength, and (c) temporal and spatial resolution (9–12).However, pH and enzymatic activity are among themost commonly reported chemical stimuli for polymeric materials (13). pH-responsive polymers can be used in fields ranging from medicine to catalysis, where pH is a vital controlled environmental parameter (14–16). Polymers have been developed with functional groups that are selectively degraded by enzymes, and the selectivity toward these enzymes when active is an attractive feature of these responsive polymers (17).
Responsive polymers can be processed into many geometries, including nanoparticles (NPs) (e.g., micelles, vesicles, and hollow spheres) and other nanostructures, such as nanogels and nanocomposites. Owing to their inherent responsive nature, these polymeric systems can be used to fabricate smart materials with tailored capabilities, for instance, sustained release of therapeutics in drug delivery, enhanced sensing in the detection of trace compounds, adaptable textiles with switchable surface properties, and on–off membrane separation technology (see Figure 1) (18–23). In this review, we provide a focused summary of pH-, thermo-, photo-, and enzymeresponsive polymers and their use as NPs and other nanostructured geometries that have enabled the aforementioned applications. Finally, we conclude with a brief prospective for future work.

sections.heading: RESPONSIVE POLYMERS pH-Responsive Polymers
sections.text:
pH-responsive polymers undergo changes in chain conformation, surface activity, and solubility upon changes in solution pH. They can be classified into two groups: polyacids and polybases. Weak acidic groups in polymers release protons at high pH, whereas weak basic groups accept protons at low pH. The polymers, therefore, behave as polyelectrolytes at the appropriate acidic or basic conditions depending on their respective pKa values (4). Some of the most common acidic groups incorporated into polymers include carboxylic, phosphonic, sulfonic, and boronic acid groups. The most common monomers used to synthesize polymers containing carboxylic acid groups are acrylic acid (AAc), methacrylic acid, maleic anhydride, and N,N-dimethylaminoethyl methacrylate (DMAEMA), as shown in Figure 2a (24–27). Phosphonic acid–functionalized polymers are usually prepared by treating natural or synthetic polymers with different phosphonic acids, such as vinyl phosphonic acid and phosphorus-based (meth)acrylate (28–30). sections.heading: Photo-Responsive Polymers
sections.text:
Photo-responsive polymers undergo changes in chemical constitution and physical properties upon exposure to ultraviolet (UV), visible, or near-infrared (NIR) light.As shown inFigure 4a, according to specific photochemical properties, three important classes of photosensitive functional groups are those that trigger (a) dimerization, (b) isomerization, or (c) self-annihilation. Polymer chains and their assemblies containing such functional groups can lead to responsive systems in which light triggers changes in physical properties or morphological conversions, e.g., crosslinking, dissociation, or shape change (49, 50).
Photo-induced dimerization of functional groups, as observed for coumarin or cinnamyl, takes place upon irradiation with specific wavelengths of light that trigger either the forward or reverse reactions (51). Reversible isomerization between the cis and trans configurations can also be triggered by light. Derivatives of azobenzene, stilbene, and spiropyran isomerize when exposed to light and can result in actuation of soft matter when incorporated into polymers (52). Irradiation can also lead to the deprotection of chemically protected bonds, as is the case for o-nitrobenzyl, thus triggering chemical instability and material degradation (53). Figure 4b illustrates two photo-responsive polymers, poly(ethylene glycol)-block-poly(dimethylamino-azobenzene) (PEGb-PMDA-Azo) and poly(N-acryloylmorpholine)-o-nitrobenzyl–poly(N-acryloylmorpholine) (PNAM-ONB-PNAM), containing azobenzene and benzyl ester moieties, respectively (54, 55).

sections.heading: RESPONSIVE POLYMERIC NANOPARTICLES AND NANOSTRUCTURES
sections.text:
Responsive polymers can be engineered into a variety of geometries to exploit their unique properties. Of particular interest are NPs and related nanostructures, as their high surface area–tovolume ratio can lead to an enhanced response to an environmental trigger. Furthermore, a range of applications, including drug delivery, membrane separations, sensors, and catalysis, are enabled by the use of polymeric materials restricted to nanoscale dimensions. In this section, we highlight how responsive polymers can be turned into nanosystems including micelles, vesicles, and capsules, which respond to an external stimulus.

sections.heading: Micelles
sections.text:
Micelles of amphiphilic block copolymers (i.e., polymers containing two dissimilar blocks within a single chain) spontaneously self-assemble in aqueous environments (59, 60). These micelles are generally spherical in shape and range in size from 10 nm to 100 nm in diameter depending on polymer molecular weight and chemistry. The hydrophobic blocks of the amphiphilic copolymers collapse to form the core of the micelle, whereas the hydrophilic blocks constitute the corona. Incorporating responsive moieties into one or both of the blocks is one means of creating responsive micelles.
In certain cases, micelle formation and morphology can be controlled by tuning physical and chemical conditions such as pH, temperature, light exposure, and enzyme. For example, the use of 2-(diethylamino)ethyl methacrylate (DEA) with poly(propylene oxide) (PPO) to create a PPOb–DEA copolymer resulted in the formation of dual pH- and thermo-responsive micelles (61). At 5°C and pH 8.5, the DEA block formed the hydrophobic micelle core and the PPO block formed the corona, whereas at 40°C and pH 6.5 the micelle structure inverted to one in which the DEA and PPO formed the corona and core, respectively, as shown inFigure 5a (61).Gao and colleagues (42) have reported dual pH-responsive micelles via the self-assembly of PDMAEMA-b-PDPA for small interfering RNAdelivery. In another example,micelles formed using the Y-shapedmiktoarm AB2 star polypeptide poly(L-lysine)-block-[poly(L-glutamic acid)]2 [PLL-b-(PLGA)2] copolymer exhibited a switchable morphology (coil-to-helix or helix-to-coil transitions) under acidic and alkaline conditions, respectively (Figure 5b) (62).Mezzenga and coworkers (63) reported a polypeptide block copolymer as a robust light-responsive system. The spiropyran-decorated amphiphilic block copolymer poly(L-glutamic acid)-spiropyran-block-polyethylene oxide formed micelles that underwent a reversible aggregation–dissolution in water triggered by exposure to UV and visible light, respectively, as illustrated in Figure 5c.

sections.heading: Vesicles
sections.text:
Vesicles, also known as polymersomes, are spherical shell structures in which an aqueous compartment is surrounded by a bilayer membrane consisting of amphiphilic block copolymers. Vesicles possess unique properties, such as the ability to encapsulate both hydrophilic and hydrophobic compounds, thus making them attractive materials in numerous fields ranging from drug/gene delivery to sensors. pH-responsive vesicles are prepared via the incorporation of acidic or basic functional groups (or monomers), such as those discussed in the section titled pH-Responsive Polymers, into the polymer chain. In one example, a pH-responsive polymer vesicle was created by the aqueous self-assembly of carboxy-terminated hyperbranched polyesters in which the vesicle size (between 10 and 200 nm) could be tuned by varying pH and, subsequently, the ionization state of the carboxyl groups (67). Luo & Eisenberg (68) prepared block copolymer vesicles from polystyrene-block-poly(acrylic acid) (PS-b-PAA) in a solution of dioxane/detrahydrofuran/H2O or dimethyl formamide/detrahydrofuran/H2O. The vesicle sizes could be reversibly tuned by increasing or decreasing the water content in a THF/dioxane solvent mixture. Gnanou and colleagues (69) reported on amphiphilic poly(butadiene)-block-poly(c-L-glutamic acid) (PB-b-PGA) diblock copolymer vesicles, which underwent a reversible coil-helix transition in response to a change in pH. Consequently, the vesicle sizes ranged from 100 to 150 nm.
McCormick and coworkers (70) prepared a thermo-responsive vesicle system via the selfassembly of the hydrophilic-hydrophilic copolymer poly[N-(3-aminopropyl)methacrylamide hydrochloride] (PAMPA)-b-PNIPAM directly in water through variation of the solution temperature, as illustrated in Figure 6a. Increasing the temperature of the aqueous solution from 25°C to 45°C led to the formation of homogeneous vesicles with a diameter of ∼280 nm. Schubert and coworkers (71) demonstrated that the block copolymer poly[DMAEMA-block-di(ethylene glycol) methyl ether methacrylate] [poly(DMAEMA-b-DEGMA)] underwent a two-step thermoinduced self-assembly process, which led to the formation of multi-lamellar vesicles above the first LCST (∼33°C) and of uni-lamellar vesicles above the second LCST (∼49°C).
Zhao and colleagues (72) reported on the formation of a photo-responsive vesicle from PAzo-b-(tBA-AA) copolymers, in which PAzo is a hydrophobic methacrylate-based azobenzene containing a side chain of a liquid crystalline polymer and tBA-AA is the hydrophilic copolymer poly(tert-butyl acrylate-coacrylic acid). When exposed to UV irradiation, the transition of the PAzo block from hydrophobic to hydrophilic changes the hydrophilic/hydrophobic balance in the copolymer, thus leading to dissociation of the vesicle. Schönherr and coworkers (73) reported the formation of enzyme-degradable polymer vesicles using hyaluronic acid-blockpoly(ε-caprolactone) (HYA-b-PCL) copolymers. The vesicle structure of HYA-b-PCL was selectively degraded by hyaluronidase, which could be exploited to enable concomitant cargo release, as shown in Figure 6b.

sections.heading: Capsules
sections.text:
Capsules, in which the hollow interior can be used to store materials of interest and the exterior shell acts as a responsive and protective barrier, are another class of responsive nanomaterials. The most common production method is templated synthesis. In this approach, a solid shell layer is polymerized atop the surface of a seed NP, which acts as a template. The template is subsequently etched away, thereby resulting in a solid capsule with a hollow interior. Caruso and coworkers (79) used a silica core and mesoporous silica shell NP (SC/MS) as a template for the preparation of pH-responsive polymeric capsules. In a multistep procedure, a poly(allylamine hydrochloride) layer was deposited atop the SC/MS template via solution adsorption. After crosslinking the polymer shell and subsequently removing the SC/MS template, they obtained a thick-walled pH-responsive polymer nanocapsule. The same group also prepared hollow polymer capsules via layer-by-layer templating of colloidal NPs. These capsules were stable at physiological pH and were degraded upon exposure to lysosomal hydrolase or through mercaptan disulfide exchange reactions (79–81). Liu and colleagues (82) prepared template-assisted biodegradable and pH-responsive polymer capsules via RAFT polymerization, using silica NPs as the template for surface grafting of PAA or PAA-co-[poly(polyethylene glycol) acrylate] (PAA-co-PPEGA), as shown in Figure 7b. In addition to templated synthesis, interfacial polymerization can be used to prepare stimuli-responsive capsules. For example, Cerruti and colleagues (83) prepared photo-responsive nanocapsules based on crosslinked polyamide mini-emulsion interfacial polymerization.

sections.heading: Nanogels
sections.text:
Responsive nanogels with feature sizes ranging from 1 nm to 1,000 nm are polymeric networks that undergo changes in volume, water content, hydrophilicity, and permeability by tuning the extent of crosslinking. Nanogels are usually prepared by monomer or polymer self-assembly and subsequent crosslinking via covalent or noncovalent interactions. Nanogels can be pH responsive through one of two mechanisms: (a) Nanogels prepared with basic monomers become positively charged and expand by accepting protons at low pH, or (b) nanogels prepared with acidic monomers become negatively charged by releasing protons and expand at high pH (4). For instance, Argentiere et al. (84) synthesized a pH-responsive nanogel of poly(methyl acrylate)poly(methacrylic acid) (PMA-PMAA) via emulsion copolymerization of methacrylic acid and methyl acrylate.
Nanogels that respond to physical stimuli of temperature and light can also be synthesized. Wang et al. (85) reported on a thermo-responsive nanogel prepared by radical polymerization of chitosan and NIPAAm with AAm. The heterogeneous nanogel exhibited the same LCST as the homopolymer of NIPAAm at ∼37°C.Hamachi and coworkers (86) used a supramolecular hydrogelator to prepare a photo-responsive nanogel droplet that underwent a sol-gel transition upon exposure toUV light.Tan and colleagues (87) developed aNIR-responsive nanogel by coating AuAg NRs with DNA-crosslinked polyacrylamide shells. Upon NIR irradiation, the photo-thermal effect of the Au-Ag NRs led to a rapid increase of the surrounding gel temperature, resulting in gel swelling. Finally, enzyme-responsive nanogels have also been reported in the literature. For instance, Jia and colleagues (88) constructed a poly(amido amine)-based enzyme-sensitive nanogel that enabled high drug loadings and exhibited sustained release of doxorubicin hydrochloride initiated by enzyme attack, as shown in Figure 8.

sections.heading: Sensors
sections.text:
Smart sensors using responsive polymers have attracted significant attention owing to their inherent characteristics of high sensitivity, fast response time, and reusability (103). Thermo-responsive polymers with different LCSTs, e.g., homopolymers or copolymers of N-tert-butylacrylamide (NTBAM), N-isopropylmethacrylamide, and NIPAM, serve as the basis for polymer-based NP thermometers. For example, the copolymer poly(DBD-AE-co-DMAPAM-co-NTBAM), based on the monomers of 4-N-(2-acryloyloxyethyl)-N-methylamino-7-N,N-dimethylaminosulfonyl2,1,3-benzoxadiazole (DBD-AE), N,N-dimethylaminopropylacrylamide (DMAPAM), and NTBAM, has been used as a polymer-based fluorescent molecular thermometer. The copolymer exhibited a strong intrinsic fluorescence emission intensity only at temperatures above its LCST of ∼35°C. The thermal phase transition from solution state to NP aggregate rendered the microenvironment of the DBD functional group hydrophobic (as opposed to hydrophilic in solution), which resulted in a considerable increase in fluorescence quantum yield of the thermometer, as shown in Figure 10 (104).
pH-responsive polymeric sensors have been prepared based on similar design principles. For instance, Jo and coworkers (105) demonstrated that poly(sulfadimethoxine) end terminated with pyrene and coumarin can be used as a promising ratiometric pH sensor. At pH values below 7, the polymer chains collapsed and aggregated, forming NPs that enhanced the Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET) efficiency between pyrene and coumarin, whereas above pH 7, the chains expanded and FRET efficiency decreased. Another strategy for building pH sensors is to employ responsive polymers functionalized with pH-sensitive dyes. To this end, Pietsch et al. (106) prepared random copolymers of DEGMA and Dispersed Red 1–based azo monomers that acted as dual pH and thermo-sensors through the solubility transition from a thermo-responsive polymer and a pH-responsive solvatochromic dye.

sections.heading: Separation Membranes
sections.text:
Significant work has been devoted to the development of separation membranes that respond to a range of external stimuli and can be used to regulate mass transfer and interfacial properties (107–110). In the case of pH-responsive systems, membranes have been prepared from basic polymers such as PDMA and P4VP, as well as from acidic polymers such as PMAA, PAMPS, poly(methacryloyl ethylene phosphate) (PMEP), and PAA (30). For instance, in the case of a PMEP-functionalized membrane, an increase in solution pH from 4 to 8 resulted in a distinct increase in the selectivity of Fe(CN6)3− over Ru(NH3)63+, indicating the ability of PMEP brushmodified mesoporous silica membranes to act as selective electrostatic nanovalves, blocking and facilitating the transport of anions and cations, respectively (110).
Thermo-responsive membranes are also of great interest (21, 111, 112). For example, Lue et al. (113) demonstrated that PNIPAAm-grafted polycarbonate (PC) membranes could be made to exhibit dramatic changes in permeability by varying temperature (Figure 11a). At temperatures above and below the LCST of PNIPAAm, the ratios of permeability for water, 4- acetamidophenol, and ranitidine hydrochloride were found to be 25.7, 11.5, and 20.1, respectively. In another example, Ying and coworkers (111) revealed that the copolymer poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF)-g-PNIPAAm could serve as a thermo-responsive microfiltration membrane, and that upon increasing the NIPAAm content in the copolymer, the resulting membranes exhibited greater thermo-responsive swelling. The ability to control membrane swelling behavior was used to control permeation of drugs by the swelling and release behavior of the PVDF-g-PNIPAAm membranes. Moreover, the effect of temperature on the pore sizes of PNIPAAm membranes was also used to separate macromolecules based on size selectivity.
The most common photo-responsive membranes are those that incorporate chromophores that undergo light-induced isomerization within the polymeric structure (114, 115). For example, Minoura et al. (116) showed that a photo-responsive polymeric membrane containing azobenzene chromophores could be created using p-phenylazoacrylanilide as a photosensitive monomer and dansylamide (DA) as a template. The specificity of DA-accurate recognition sites in molecularly imprinted polymer membranes could be reversibly tuned by UV and visible light illumination. In another case, Nayak et al. sections.heading: Textiles
sections.text: Textiles containing responsive phase-change polymer materials can store heat energy in hightemperature environments and release that heat in low-temperature environments (118). One of the most commonly used phase-change polymers is PEG, which has a melting temperature between 3.2°C and 68.7°C depending on its molecular weight. In one instance, Aly et al. (119) prepared a cotton product that could be used in medical textiles by graftingN-phthaloyl-chitosanb-PEG copolymer/citric acid into the cotton fabrics. Additionally, Liu &Hu (120) reported on the inclusion of thermo-responsive PNIPAAm graft layers in textiles to fabricate thermo-responsive hygroscopic fabrics. The swelling/shrinkage or hydration/dehydration characteristics could cause changes in water vapor transmission rate and gas permeability upon external stimuli. Chen et al. (121) also fabricated an easily removable temperature-responsive wound dressing by grafting chitosan with thermo-responsive PNIPAAm onto plasma-induced graft polymerization–modified nonwoven fabrics.

sections.heading: Catalysis
sections.text: Smart catalysis can improve the mass transfer of reactants and products in solution, impart on and off control to catalytic pathways, and facilitate the separation and recovery of precious catalyst from reaction mixtures (122–125). For pH-responsive catalysis, Zhang and coworkers (126, 127) found that a series of core-shell NPs could be exploited for Suzuki and Heck reactions in aqueous media. The core-shell NP catalysts consisted of the following architectures: (a) a pHresponsive shell of PMAA and a coordination core of poly[2-(acetoacetoxy)ethyl methacrylate] and PS; (b) a pH-responsive shell of PGMA-iminodiacetic acid (IDA) and a PS core; and (c) a pH-responsive shell of PMAA-IDA and a PS core. Owing to the swelling/deswelling behavior of the pH-responsive shells upon changes in pH, the dispersion of the catalyst could be tuned. In addition, Zhang and coworkers (128, 129) showed that PNIPAM-enabled thermo-responsive AufunctionalizedNPs could be used as smart nanoreactors to catalyze the reduction of p-nitrophenol to p-aminophenol in the presence of NaBH4. Below the LCST of PNIPAM, the chains were hydrophilic and the reactants could easily diffuse through the PNIPAM corona to reach the surface of the AuNPs. Above the LCST,PNIPAM chains collapsed to form a hydrophobic barrier around the Au NPs, which decelerated diffusion of the reactants.

sections.heading: CONCLUSIONS
sections.text:
Smart NP systems, based on the exploitation of responsive polymers, are being developed for a wide range of applications.Here, we have highlighted four of the most commonly reported classes of such materials: pH-, thermo-, photo-, and enzyme-responsive polymers. We also discussed their use as NPs and related nanostructured geometries for applications in drug delivery, sensors, separation membranes, textiles, and catalysis.
Though tremendous advances have been made, challenges remain in the field of responsive polymer systems (and nanostructures made from them). Developing new monomers through green chemistries is one challenge of preparing new responsive polymers. metadata.abstractText: Responsive polymers undergo reversible or irreversible physical or chemical modifications in response to a change in environment or stimulus, e.g., temperature, pH, light, and magnetic or electric fields. Polymeric nanoparticles (NPs), which constitute a diverse set of morphologies, including micelles, vesicles, and core-shell geometries, have been successfully prepared from responsive polymers and have shown great promise in applications ranging from drug delivery to catalysis. In this review, we summarize pH, thermo-, photo-, and enzymatic responsiveness for a selection of polymers. We then discuss the formation of NPs made from responsive polymers. Finally, we highlight how NPs and other nanomaterials are enabling a wide range of smart applications with improved efficiency, as well as improved sustainability and recyclability of polymeric systems. 361 A nn u.
